text:
When I am running ant on my AIX box then I am getting the following error even though the build.xml exist in the same directory

> ant -v
Apache Ant(TM) version 1.8.4 compiled on May 22 2012
Trying the default build file: build.xml
./build.xml is not an absolute path


However if I give the absolute path then it's working. 

I have been working on Ant from several years, I have never faced this kind of problem.

I am not sure whether it's a bug in Ant 1.8.4 version or something bad in my setup.

I have checked that CLASSPATH is also empty.

Here is my build.xml

---------------------------------------------------------

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<project name="install" basedir="." default="test">
<property environment="env" />
<target name="test">
<echo message="ernitingoel"/>
</target>

</project>
---------------------------------------------------------

Could you please help me to get rid of this error?
creator: ernitingoel@hotmail.com
bodewig@apache.org
text:
could this be some strange shell script named ant in your path that adds ./build.xml all by itself?

Otherwise output of -debug including the full stacktrace might give us more infomation.

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
OK, let's see.

The only place in Ant's source code that emits this kind of error is in FileUtils#disect which is called from normalize which again is invoked from Ant's main method but it does so like this

            FileUtils.getFileUtils().normalize(buildFile.getAbsolutePath());

now I wonder how buildFile.getAbsolutePath() can ever return ./build.xml and not an absolute path.

Can you give us the output of ant -diagnostics?

Also, can write a small program to test whether new File("build.xml").getAbsolutePath() really doesn't return an absolute path?

creator: ernitingoel@hotmail.com

./build.xml
creator: ernitingoel@hotmail.com

text:
I don't think your Java implementation is allowed to do that, getAbsolutePath is guaranteed to return an absolute path. :-(

And there isn't much Ant can do, I'm afraid.  Ant needs the absolute path in several places.

One likely problem I see is the value for the user.dir property which contains "." in your case, it contains an absolute path on any other systen I've seen so far.  Is there some wrapper script involved that overrides system properties?
creator: bodewig@apache.org

text: OTOH the value of user.dir may just be another symptom rather than the problem.
creator: bodewig@apache.org

text:
I agree, I think we can close this bug then.

Let me see why my Java program is behaving like that.
